awd_titl_txt: Network Hemodynamics: A Computational Study of Cellular Blood Flow and Particulate Transport in Microvascular Capillary Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1604308
PI: Bagchi, Prosenjit

This award provides for support for numerical simulations and microfluidics-based experiments to study blood flow in small vessels and to examine the distribution of red blood cells among various branches of the vascular tree.  Although this is a long-standing problem, the combination of advanced computations and experiments will provide new insights to help explain observations reported in the literature over decades.  The numerical computations will examine the partitioning of red cells at vessel bifurcations where a vessel splits into two vessels and at locations where vessels recombine.  The simulations will also examine time-dependent flow variations that are intrinsic to flow through vessel networks.  Results from simulations will be compared with experiments of blood flow through microfluidic channels and networks of channels.  The results of the project will be useful to scientists and engineers who work in areas such as tissue engineering, intravenous drug delivery, and in the design of blood-handling devices.  The research will be incorporated into a summer course for high-school students titled "Computational Methods in Science and Engineering."  Undergraduates, especially those from underrepresented groups, will be recruited to participate in the research.

A three-dimensional, multiscale direct numerical simulation will be developed for deformable, poly-disperse blood cells flowing through networks of bifurcating, merging, and tortuous vessels.  The model will include evolving cellular interfaces governed by hyper-viscoelastic constitutive laws and intricate stationary boundaries defined by the network architecture.  The overall model will combine an immersed boundary method, a finite element method for interface deformation and a stochastic Monte-Carlo method for coarse-graining molecular interactions.  The model will be validated by comparison with experiments of blood flow in networks of microfluidic channels.  These tools will be used to examine the influence of network architecture on the distribution of blood cells, the network flow resistance, and the growth of self-sustained flow oscillations.  The model will also be used to examine the influence of network architecture on the formation of blood clots and on deposition of drug-bearing particles.  The results of this project will provide an organ-scale model of blood flow that retains cellular-scale dynamics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Capillary blood vessels in human body are the 'final frontiers' in blood circulation system as they perform the crucial role of delivering oxygen and metabolites to tissues. These vessels are the smallest diameter vessel and they form intricate network with frequent vessel branching, merger, and tortuous vessels. Red blood cells, the oxygen carrier, have to navigate through such intricate passages. Often the diameter of such vessels is smaller than a cell size, and red cells can squeeze through such narrow vessels because of their extreme deformability. These vessels play major roles in many diseases, such as sickle cell disease, diabetes mellitus, Alzheimer's disease, and heart diseases. Because of such importance, a plethora of studies has been directed to understand flow of red cells in capillary vessels. Experimental techniques are sometimes limited as they cannot provide fully 3D information of time- and space-resolved motion of individual and many red cells in a capillary network over a large tissue area. To overcome this limitation, theoretical and computer modeling has been used to predict the flow of blood in capillary vessel networks. In order to make calculations tractable, these previous theoretical models simplified the network geometry, for example, by assuming that the blood vessels are one-dimensional straight segments. They also used empirical laws of blood viscosity and assumed simple pressure--flow relationships for blood flow in vessels.

To overcome these limitations of theoretical models, we have developed a high-fidelity, fully 3D computational model that retains the exact geometric details of capillary vascular networks as observed in vivo under a microscope, such as 3D bifurcations, mergers, and tortuous vessels. It also considers 3D deformation of every red cell flowing. Using this model we have performed simulations of flow of large number of blood cells through physiologically realistic capillary vessel networks. Our results have revealed several novel and unexpected findings, and provided new insights of previously known phenomena of microcirculatory blood flow. We predicted cell lingering at vascular bifurcations causing a significant increase in resistance to blood flow. We also provided novel insights on how cells are distributed as they flow through bifurcations, and showed that point particle modeling of red cells significantly mispredict cell distribution at bifurcations. We also provided, for the first time, a full 3D quantification of red cell-depleted region near the surface of vessels, and wall shear stress. We also performed microfluidic experiments to support our numerical finding of red cell lingering. Furthermore, we have studied motion of deformable cells in curved flows, and predicted that at low inertia a cell would migrate toward the interior side of the vessel, but at higher inertia it moves toward the center of the vortex.

We have published eight journal articles, and trained two PhD students in the multidisciplinary area of computational modeling, flow dynamics, and biomechanics. One PhD student has won 2019 Andreas Acrivos Dissertation award from the American Physical Society, and is currently an assistant professor at an university. We have presented our results in many conferences. Our research was featured in journal Cover, selected as Most Read articles, and was publicized in other outlets.


Last Modified: 12/27/2021
Modified by: Prosenjit Bagchi
